reasoning: Cruciality is high because the core strategic fork in the paper is whether compute is a hard bottleneck (rho materially < 0) versus near–Cobb–Douglas (rho≈0), which would shift emphasis between compute/hardware governance and rapid-takeoff preparedness. Paper-specificity is very high: it directly interrogates the paper’s central quantitative move (mapping rho to max-speed ceilings and the claim -0.2<rho<0). Tractability is the main weakness: estimating an ‘effective rho’ for post-OAI AI R&D over 1–5 OOM increases in L is only partially operationalisable and would rely on uncertain proxies, modeling assumptions, or limited early-post-OAI data rather than clean empirical identification. Clarity is good but not perfect because ‘AI cognitive labour’, ‘after OAI’, and ‘effective rho across 1–5 OOM’ leave room for interpretation (how to measure L, what tasks count as R&D, whether rho is constant or piecewise). Decision hook is excellent with explicit action-relevant thresholds. Dead weight is low; the worldview/implication bullets add some non-essential text but don’t obscure the question.
title: Compute-labor substitutability elasticity in post-OAI AI R&D
